subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] The principles of my dictionary
msgSnippet: ... And /A/, as in some pronunciations of palm itself. ... By no means.  It really is /tAk/ in Canada and the American West, and one of the ways they make
messageBody:
Benct Philip Jonsson scripsit:

> The rub, which I hadn't really appreciated yet, is the TO
> spelling _al_, which may correspond to all of /Ol/, /O/,
> /Ql/, /Al/, /al/, with some of the alternatives (except /al/
> varying by accent!

And /A/, as in some pronunciations of "palm" itself.

> _talk_ is always /tOk/

By no means. It really is /tAk/ in Canada and the American West, and
one of the ways they make fun of us Easterners, especially New Yorkers,
is to write about how we "tawk". (In proper NYC dialect, the word is
more like [to@k] ~ [tO@k].)

> pronunciation ranges from /tuzde/ over /tjuzde/ to /cuzde/

Except for us gangsters who went from /de/ to /dI/ to /di/.

> The older formulation should be scratched since I forgot
> that word-initial //lju// behaves differently depending on
> whether it follows after a consonant or not, unlike
> //rju//, as well as forgetting the _ui, eu_ and _ew_ TO
> spelling variants.

In addition, I don't think /rju/ ever existed: as far as I can make out
from the OED's indications (its pronunciation guide in unrevised entries
is very conservative indeed), the word went straight from /rIUd/ to /rud/,
except in the remnant /IU/ accent areas.

(In Scots it's "ruid", originally [r2d], now usually [rId] but also [ryd],
[rYd], [r9d], [rid], [red], [r8d] depending on dialect, but in any case
with no trace of iotation. All forms in true X-SAMPA.)

> > You spelling proposal is attractive. Americans can still
> > use their ear to spell words except for words in the PALM
> > lexical set, which I am to understand is very small.
>
> Exactly, only about 80 words, not counting uncommon foreign
> names, and it corresponds to those cases where /A/
> corresponds to TO _a_ not followed by _l, r, u_ or _w_, so
> it can be learnt by rule.

Do you actually have long lists of words in various lexical sets,
or are you quoting Wells? (Gotta get those books one day soon.)
In any case, "palm" is in PALM whether you pronounce the "l" or
not, but it doesn't fit the given rule.

> Yes, that's the idea. Also Americans pronouncing CLOTH words
> with /O/ -- mainly Easterners -- would have to make an
> adjustment to 'unphonetic' spelling.

And in quite a lot of words: CLOTH is not, I believe,
anywhere near as small as PALM.

--
John Cowan cowan@... ccil.org/~cowan
Dievas dave dantis; Dievas duos duonos --Lithuanian proverb
Deus dedit dentes; deus dabit panem --Latin version thereof
Deity donated dentition;
deity'll donate doughnuts --English version by Muke Tever
God gave gums; God'll give granary --Version by Mat McVeagh
